displayed_text: Patient: And that’s when he recommended I see an oncologist there. He teaches up here, too, so. He’s kind of the go-between. And he’s the one that said he’d work on the lung problem. Doctor: Just a couple more things So other than the CAT scan you haven’t had any other new scans? Patient: Not for I think about two months, three months, and I had the whole-body scan ordered by I think the thoracic surgeon V___ and that’s been the three lymph nodes on the lungs. Doctor: And that’s all you know from the last time you were here. Patient: Oh no, not since the last time I was here, no, just that one. Doctor: Okay, uh so the test results that we have is your ARV7 test. Dr. G but we had one- Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: and that came back as positive. So some transcripts are negative and some transcripts are positive. But that’s generally considered a positive test, which is a negative thing. Patient: Oh (chuckles) Doctor: And we tried to get your tissues set out for genetic testing, and it wasn’t enough or inadequate for them to run any tests on it. So we don’t have any more data about molecular testing. Dr. G mentions it in his note as well that that’s something that he wants to do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I don’t know where he is with that as to whether he’s going to try a different company or other tissue that he may have. And I don’t know what they sent. Did they send the tissue from your liver or tissue from back when you were first diagnosed? Patient: I don’t know.

Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: FDA approved. We would do a different chemo. I wouldn’t repeat the same chemo but it’s a cousin drug so it’s still once every three weeks just like before. Okay, the pills are four pills a day every day. Patient: For the rest of your life? Doctor: Yeah, until it stops working, which at some point after a couple years it sort of poops out and stops working. So, we have studies there too. So, you got to say okay, what’s this study with the chemo. Well, you know in Oncology we love to combine stuff so the study is either the pill or chemo plus the pill. I know. So, it’s a win-win in the sense that you either get the pill get the pill that you were going to get anyways Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: or you actually get the double whammy and you get the pill and Patient: and the chemo. Doctor: the chemo and that’s a nationwide study so, you know, we would pretty much kind of consider that one for you. And then there’s another trial of just pills. You say, listen, Dr. H____ there’s no way your’e giving me any more chemo, get away from me, then there’s a study with two pills so the one pill that I would offer you and then another pill that is also FDA approved but you know in cancer it’s like hey, one’s good, let’s try two. So, the combo isn’t chemo plus pill, but it’s pill plus pill. How are we doing? Patient: I’m there. Doctor: Yeah, I can see it. It’s kind of a lot but the good news is there’s a lot of options and that’s me banking on everything as the worse-case scenario as, you know, you know, Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: that’s how I am because I don’t want you to fret that there’s nothing to do after we get the scans. We have tons of stuff to do. It’s just being thoughtful about what you want in terms of what’s the best thing. Questions? Patient: Not on that. I had one other.

Family Member: Wow. Doctor: Yeah, the chemo class will sorta tell you a little bit about what’s more, like normal. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, you know, you’re gonna likely - you know seventy-five percent of people lose their hair on this. Family Member: So, is that - Doctor: And that tends to grow back Family Member: That class, is that here? Or is that a web cast? Doctor: No, it’s here. Family Member: It’s here. Patient: Any need for a driver - chemo days, things like that? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So, on chemo days, you have to have a driver. Ummm. You may not need him. But, I mean, my sense is that if you start getting sick and nauseated, and I have to give you a medicine that’s sedating - I don’t want you getting behind the wheel of a car and driving home.

Healthcare Professional: Yes! Doctor: Yep! Healthcare Professional: Do your thing. Family Member: Hey. How are you? Doctor: I hear I’m missing the show in here. Patient: Your hands are cold, doc. Doctor: I just washed ‘em. How are you? Family Member: They are cold. Doctor: Okay! What are we going to do? (chair movement) Family Member: Can you -- I’m lost here. Can you repeat – uh, why -- are you saying that he could go on the next trial? Doctor: You could try a trial and see how you do – Patient: Right. Doctor: And then, if somewhere along the way, it improves, great. I’m talkin’ about the fistula and this whole –

Patient: Right. Doctor: But that’s something may not be so as aggressive or as detrimental on your quality of life as the hormone therapy, for example, which has all these systemic side effects. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So I wasn’t necessarily seeing it as hormones plus radiation at the same time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I was seeing it as doing the radiation therapy as a way to sort of avoid or push back the need for the hormones. Family Member: Because the radiation is just going to target that one area. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Correct. Family Member: And the cancer still. Healthcare Professional: But the thing is, too, you’ll also be observed. You know so you’ll still be getting PSA levels done. I don’t know when he will repeat scans but you’ll get another set of scans. So it’s not; it’s not like you wouldn’t still have information along the way to like initiate the hormones if it comes after the you know – Patient: Okay.

Patient: Just physically tired? Doctor: Physically tired and it’s a weirder tired not like you worked out in the yard for twelve hours and can’t do much, it’s just no get up and go. If that happens, we take a break and we reduce the medicine dose. Patient: Let me ask you something doc. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Can we, can we provide a pill that would give me a little, like a vitamin that would give me a little energy? Doctor: No I think the issue of you not having as much energy is that your cancer is starting to, sorry that your thing is starting to break through slowly, Patient: Right. Doctor: but I don’t want to be on the back end because you you know in the story that you didn’t share Patient: Yeah. Doctor: with all the stuff related to what you’ve been doing with Dr. P____. Patient: Right. Doctor: That’s a whole ‘nother situation as you know Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. So along the way there with you say ‘well gosh what else do you need to take the samples for’ when you know us we do lots of research here. Patient: Sure. Doctor: So parts of that, I think we talked about this the last time, when I take extra samples I will then do actual research stuff on that… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …which includes you know growing it outside of you, putting it in mice, working with all – all sorts of other things. For me to do that I have to have a consent form that we’re gonna go over. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Um and uh this will allow me use with along with our other researchers for future use. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Um so you can see it was important for me to talk to the radiologist to make sure that we can do it safely and that we can get enough samples to make it worth everybody’s while. Okay. Questions. Patient: Um n- well observations. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: They – it it did say for example…

Patient: Yeah, it was a lymph node and Doctor: Right. So, they’ll be more pictures at that point. Sometimes when we use the hormones and the chemo, uh, things start to heal. Things that we can’t see now with our pictures. And, then, things pop up. Uh. And that’s just because they’re healing, so we can now see them. Uh. But your PSA is zero and you feel well with taking your prostate out, so that would then give them information as to sort of, okay this is what we can offer at that point. Patient: Okay. What’s the downside? Doctor: Umm. Downside? More therapy than you should be getting. Patient: Okay. Doctor: A lot of therapy in a young guy. So, we think you’re the right guy to get it because you can probably handle it all. Uh, but T_ and I, when we’ve been working together this last week, uh - There’s a lot of safety built in that, you know, instead of going six cycles, we could stop after four cycles. You know, some of these sorts of just tweaking things to make sure we don’t, uh, you know, go too far. And, that’s some of the reason why we see you every three weeks when you’re on the chemo. Uh. ‘Cuz we wanna make sure we’re not going too far. Uh. And, you know, the whole concept of doing this together, there is nothing about this that we haven’t done before, but it’s not around the country. And, the big question is, “Is this much therapy appropriate?” (pause) Patient: I, uh, I guess the one question that I had, um, reading the, the paperwork and then this conversation - You’re waiting until after the chemo and then four weeks after chemo before any spot radiation for any, any sites that have popped up. Why not treat the one spot now, that I’m, the, the rib? ‘Cuz you can’t operate there. And, I understand radiation pre-surgery on the prostate, probably not a really good thing to do and then have surgery. But, the rib - why not do the spot therapy? Doctor: Because the hormone’s gonna take care of that. The chemo is gonna take care of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The radiation is gravy. That’s the bow on top of the package. Patient: Gotcha, okay. So, it’s, it’s not a primary treatment then? Doctor: No. We’re going to everywhere the cancer is, whether we see it or we don’t see it. Okay? Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: And then you’ll come back and see me a week after the first injection, I mean a month after the first injection. Patient: Okay. Doctor: At that time you could let us know if you want the twelve month implant or if you want to go with the three month shot. And then we do this for about two years or so and then we stop hormone therapy. By that time you’re done with radiation therapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then we wait and see what happens. Hopefully the PSA stays low. Family Member: But during that whole two years you don’t really know what’s going on because you can’t measure it accurately right?
DOC Because the hormone therapy is suppressing what’s there and killing off ninety nine percent of it, then maybe not that last one percent, maybe, maybe not, the radiation does that. So we’re giving you all that we got. Um hum. Um hum. We want it all. Okay. Um and leakage issue. I think he’s doing pretty good, but how long does that typically take?
DOC About another month or so. A lot of times people get better suddenly. Doctor: So if you’re seeing some improvement it will just continue to get better. Patient: Yeah I was tell G___ you know it when I’m not as active there’s no problem but uh I started work last night so I can definitely feel… Doctor: That’s very common. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: You’re on the right track. Patient: Yeah.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::strongly agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Some other race: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Some other race

displayed_text: Patient: I’ve gotta box this up. You know? As it was I was a little bit late Family Member: You ate half of it. Doctor: No. That’s okay. You should never rush to come here. You know that. You just come when you can safely. I’m not going anywhere. So next time just finish whatever you’ve gotta finish. Patient: Well, we, we, we, started now much late. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But then we ran into,there’s a ballgame. Doctor: I heard there was something going on seventy-five today too. Patient: Middle of that, yes. Doctor: There was some massive drama on seventy-five. Family Member: Oh. Hope we missed it. Patient: No. We ran into it. Doctor: But it was south of here. Something happened south.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Sometimes longer than that. Family Member: Okay. Patient: At which point we’ll be transitioning to a different kind of treatment, hopefully. Doctor: Right. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: And, that’s the next discussion, what that is. And, that, that’s evolving, particularly for guys with your story. Family Member: Okay, so then you’re looking at like, like combinations of drugs? Doctor: Yeah. Normally, we would keep you on the hormone -- forever at that point, unfortunately. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And then, add things to them. Standardly, we would add another hormone, so you’d be on two. Research-wise, we would potentially consider these other drugs, particularly because of your mutation. Family Member: So, no chemo then? Doctor: No, not in, not in the short term.

Patient: And I’ll… Doctor: And today - you had blood work today though? Patient: Yes. Doctor: So we should be able to give you a PSA from that by tomorrow or the next day or two. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah so I’m thinking I can see you back in three months. In between at some point, about half way six weeks or so, I do want to repeat PSA. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: And can you get it up there? Patient: I’ll get it from C___. Doctor: Okay. Do you need a script from me? Patient: Yeah, I better. Doctor: Okay. That way it’s a reminder that you need to go get that.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - then there’s no question that hormone therapy will cause more side effects than radiation. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: There’s no question about that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, if your goal is to try to eradicate as much of the cancer as fast as possible – Family Member: Um hum. DOC - then the best way to do that although it’s still not a cure is hormone therapy plus or minus something else. So something new. Doctor: Right, so there’s no question that hormone therapy within the first three months is going to kill like ninety-nine percent of the cancer. Happens with almost everyone. With radiotherapy you know there’s a decent chance that it’s going to kill whatever cancer happens to be part that we radiate – Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: - but the rest of the cancer which is going to be invisible is obviously going to be outside of that radiation field. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: It’s not going to be touched. And the concern with that is although I am a proponent of someone that wants to – If your goal is absolutely to avoid hormone therapy as long as possible, that’s a good option for you. And again, what would be driving that would be more quality of life.

Healthcare Professional: Yep, she just has to sign these first. So… Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: They won't take them without her signature. Doctor: I’m just a - I’m just wondering, how long did we wait? We waited two weeks now? Healthcare Professional: It was two weeks from-- Doctor: Two weeks from his last uh, when he was last due? Healthcare Professional: Yeah Doctor: Okay. So then I- for now I'm going to stay with the same dose. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I think the next step before this tearing and everything, and we are getting up there in number of cycles you've gotten, Patient: Correct. Doctor: we may need to consider cutting back on the dose or--

Family Member: That’s all right. (doors closing) Patient: They are? Good. Family Member: you’re eating. Doctor: I know about one again. Patient: The first time I went that was at the beginning, just like taking a shot, a few days after that I was throwing up every day for four days. And I talked to your assistant on email, and he said to go to emergency, and so we went and the problem was I wasn’t urinating properly. So they put a catheter in. Doctor: Let me stop you one second. Let’s, let me review some of the paperwork – Patient: Sure. So you can concentrate. Doctor: So uh you’re still taking the Bicalutamide or have you finished that -- the Casodex? Patient: What is that? Doctor: Uh what the pill that you took two weeks before I gave you the shot. Family Member: Yes, that’s done. The hormone - Patient: Yeah, yeah, that’s -
